The combination of positive HBsAg, negative anti-HBs, and positive anti-HBc IgG indicates a chronic HBV infection. In chronic HBV infection, negative HBeAg with positive anti-HBe typically indicates low viral replication, high HBV clearance, and low disease activity (inactive chronic disease).

The combination of positive anti-HBs, negative anti-HBc, and negative HBsAg indicates immunity to HBV infection due to vaccination. This patient, who had a negative anti-HBs test 6 months ago, was not adequately vaccinated against HBV. He was offered hepatitis B vaccination as a result of his high-risk status (i.e., intravenous drug use) but he refused vaccination and subsequently developed HBV infection.

The largest group of patients with chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infections are inactive carriers. In these patients, the immune system's response slows viral replication, which is why HBeAg (an indicator of viral replication) would be undetectable, whereas it is positive in this patient. Additionally, due to the low number of viral particles in inactive HBV infection, the disease burden would be very low and this patient's findings (e.g., elevated transaminases, icterus) would be unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Because the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is positive, the possible differentials are limited to acute, active chronic, and inactive chronic hepatitis B. HBsAg is only negative in an infected patient during the window period or if the virus is successfully cleared from circulation. In acute infection, IgM antibodies against the core antigen would be expected, however, as opposed to IgG antibodies.

C) CORRECT:

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is positive in patients with either an acute, active chronic, or an inactive chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. HBsAg is only negative in infected patients during the window period of HBV or if the infection was successfully cleared. IgG antibodies against the hepatitis B core antigen (Anti-HBc IgG) indicate either active or inactive chronic infection. The e antigen is only present during phases of viremia, which occur in acute or active chronic infections. A positive IgG antibody test rules out an acute infection, which would instead show IgM antibodies. This patient therefore most likely has an active chronic HBV infection.
Image Description:

The hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is found on the outer wall of the virions lipid bilayer and confirms the presence of the virus in the blood. HBsAg is the first indicator of infection and can be detected as early as 1 week after infection. An infected hepatocyte may also release the hepatitis B envelope antigen (HBeAg), a protein produced by the virus that serves as an indicator of active viral replication.

D) INCORRECT:

For hepatitis B virus (HBV) to be considered resolved, all viral particles must be cleared from the host. In contrast to this patient, in a patient with a resolved HBV infection, viral antigens (HBsAg, HBeAg) would be undetectable, but antibodies against the viral antigens would remain detectable (anti-HBs, anti-HBc).

E) INCORRECT:

The positive anti-HAV IgG titers in this patient indicate either vaccination or an old infection with hepatitis A virus (HAV). As both result in lifelong immunity, this laboratory constellation rules out acute infection. Additionally, if the patient had an acute HAV infection, the serology would be positive for HAV-IgM antibodies.

Short-term use of lamivudine may be considered for patients with acute HBV infection if acute liver failure develops. Lamivudine therapy may also be used to treat chronic hepatitis B when combination therapy is necessary (e.g., HIV/HBV coinfection).

B) CORRECT:

In a patient with chronic HBV infection, antiviral therapy is indicated if the patient is in the immune-active phase, i.e., has increased ALT levels (≥ 2 times the upper limit of normal) and significantly increased HBV DNA concentration (> 20,000 IU/mL in HBeAg-positive patients; > 2000 IU/mL in HBeAg-negative patients). Other indications for initiating antiviral therapy against HBV include an immunocompromised state, hepatitis C coinfection, and cirrhosis or advanced hepatic fibrosis. Therapy is aimed at reducing HBV DNA below a detectable level, achieving seroconversion (negative HBeAg with positive anti‑HBe titers), and preventing progression to end-stage liver disease.

Options for antiviral therapy against hepatitis B include tenofovir, entecavir, and pegylated interferon alpha (IFN-α). IFN-α is, however, contraindicated among pregnant women or patients with any of the following conditions: autoimmune disease (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus), uncontrolled psychiatric disease, cytopenias, severe cardiac disease, or uncontrolled seizures.

If a patient with chronic HBV infection develops decompensated cirrhosis (e.g., jaundice, coagulopathy with INR >1.5, or hepatic encephalopathy), an urgent referral to a liver transplantation center is indicated. This patient has evidence of liver inflammation (↑ ALT) but does not have any evidence of liver cirrhosis (e.g., splenomegaly, ascites).

D) INCORRECT:

Supportive treatment alone would be recommended for patients with acute HBV infection. Patients with acute HBV infection would be positive for HBsAg and HBeAg antigens. However, titers of IgG anti-HBc would be negative during an acute infection. Moreover, patients with acute HBV infection would have jaundice, massively elevated ALT and AST levels (> 500 IU/L), and systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, nausea, and/or vomiting.

In a patient with positive HBeAg titers, active follow-up every 6 months would be indicated if ALT levels were within normal limits. ALT levels that are more than twice the normal upper limit indicate moderate to severe liver inflammation. Therapy is, therefore, necessary to prevent progression to cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the office because of increasing generalized fatigue for 1 month. He also has had a 5.4 kg (12 lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has numerous tattoos, several of which were acquired when he went backpacking through Southeast Asia as a young man. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show serum α-fetoprotein of 410 ng/mL (N < 10 ng/mL). CT scan of the abdomen shows a 3.5 x 2 x 1.5 cm mass in segment 6 of the liver. Which of the following interventions most likely would have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Regular phlebotomies are performed to manage patients with hemochromatosis. Although this condition can lead to hepatocellular carcinoma, it is usually preceded by progressive liver cirrhosis, and other findings, including fatigue, hyperpigmentation, type 2 diabetes mellitus ("bronze diabetes"), hepatomegaly, and symmetrical arthralgia. This patient's symptoms are not consistent with hemochromatosis.

B) CORRECT:

Up to 50% of cases of HCC occur secondary to chronic hepatitis B (HBV) infection. Although the majority of such cases (approx. 80%) are preceded by liver cirrhosis, HCC can also arise directly from chronic HBV infection. A history of multiple tattoos that were obtained in countries with a higher prevalence of HBV and hepatitis C virus, as in this patient, should raise the suspicion of HBV infection. HBV vaccination is recommended for all unvaccinated individuals.

C) INCORRECT:

Obesity and diabetes mellitus are risk factors for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Excess supply of nutrients in the liver and increased insulin resistance result in accumulation of fat in liver cells. Patients generally do not exhibit signs of hepatic disease in the early stages of NAFLD, but progression to cirrhosis with an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) can occur. This patient does not have a history of obesity, diabetes, hepatitis, or cirrhosis.

D) INCORRECT:

CA 19–9 is a tumor marker that is produced by numerous forms of cancer and is primarily used for monitoring treatment response and detecting cancer recurrence. However, it is not a reliable screening or diagnostic marker because of its low sensitivity and low specificity.

E) INCORRECT:

Penicillamine is a chelating agent that is used to reduce extremely high levels of copper in patients with Wilson disease, which typically manifests at a young age (< 35 years) with progressive hepatitis (or even cirrhosis) and neurological disorders (extrapyramidal motor symptoms and/or cognitive impairment). These features are not consistent with this patient's presentation. Also, the absence of Kayser-Fleischer rings makes this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient presents with weight loss, fatigue, and an enlarged liver. A mass on an abdominal CT scan in the context of massively increased α-fetoprotein is highly suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

questions.text: Two months after giving birth at home, a 27-year-old woman comes to the office with her infant for a routine examination. The mother did not receive consistent prenatal care and she is unsure of her vaccination history. Physical examination of the mother and the child shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show elevated titers of hepatitis B surface antigen in both the mother and the child. Which of the following statements regarding the infant's condition is most accurate?

choices.text: Significant elevation of transaminases is not expected
Lifetime risk of hepatocellular carcinoma is low

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Transaminases are usually normal or only mildly elevated in cases of vertical transmission of HBV. Because HBV is not cytopathic itself and newborns lack mature cytotoxic T-cells that mediate damage to infected hepatocytes, the degree of hepatic tissue damage will be limited. Rarely, infected neonates may develop acute hepatitis B.

Newborns of mothers with unknown HBV status should receive vaccine within 12 hours of birth. If the mother tests positive for HBsAg, hepatitis B immune globulin should be administered as soon as possible. Newborns of HBsAg negative mothers should be given the hepatitis B vaccine series before hospital discharge.

B) INCORRECT:

The risk of hepatocellular carcinoma is significant in neonatal hepatitis. Perinatal infection with HBV carries an approximately 90 % chance of the infant becoming a chronic carrier, with an estimated 15 % to 25 % risk of dying in adulthood from cirrhosis or liver cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Without treatment, chronic course of infection is very common in neonatal hepatitis from vertical transmission. Up to 90% of infants infected perinatally will develop chronic infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Breastfeeding should be recommended to all patients with maternal HBV, as HBV infection is not a contraindication to breastfeeding. Women with HBV infection should be counseled that breastfeeding does not increase the likelihood of infection in their children. However, breastfeeding should be delayed until passive‑active postexposure prophylaxis has been given. Since, in this patient, vertical transmission of HBV has already occurred, there is no reason to delay breastfeeding.

E) INCORRECT:

HBV replicates rapidly upon entering the newborn because of the inability of the infantile immune system to mount a HBV-specific immune response. Therefore, the viral replication rate would be expected to be high, not low.
questions.hint: Elevated titers of HbsAg in both the mother and the infant suggest vertical transmission of the hepatitis B virus (HBV).

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman from Southeast Asia presents to establish care and reports no concerns. She has a history of hypertension and a prior hysterectomy, and she has previously been treated for latent tuberculosis. Physical examination is unremarkable. A hepatitis B serology panel documents negative surface antigen, positive anti-surface antibody, positive immunoglobulin G-type anti-core antibody, and negative e antigen. Which of the following clinical states do this patient’s hepatitis B serology findings indicate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute hepatitis B infection is typically associated with a positive surface antigen (HBsAg), negative anti-surface antibody (anti-HBs), positive immunoglobulin M-type anti-core antibody (anti-HBc), and a positive e antigen (HBeAg) on serology.

B) CORRECT:

The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend onetime screening for hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection in all individuals ≥ 18 years old. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends HBV screening in a narrower group of people, namely those who are pregnant and those with risk factors; this latter group includes patients from areas where HBV infection is endemic, such as parts of Southeast Asia.

Most adults who are exposed to HBV clear the infection spontaneously, but a small percentage (≤ 5%) develop persistent viremia and chronic infection. HBV surface antigen becomes detectable in the blood 4 to 10 weeks after exposure, followed by anti-core antibodies (initially, immunoglobulin M-type). In most cases, the HBV e antigen also becomes detectable around this time.

In patients who experience a self-limited course, HBV anti-surface antibody levels then rise and are accompanied by clearance of the antigens and viremia. Anti-surface antibody and immunoglobulin G-type anti-core antibodies indicate cleared HBV infection, whereas anti-surface antibody alone indicates prior HBV vaccination.

The hallmark of ongoing HBV infection is persistence of surface antigen and absence of surface antibody. A positive HBV e antigen, a marker of replication and infectivity in persistent infection, also indicates an elevated risk for hepatocellular carcinoma.

Key learning point: A hepatitis B serology panel that is positive for both anti-surface antibody and immunoglobulin G-type anti-core antibody indicates prior hepatitis B virus infection.
Image Description:

Schematic depiction of the time frames in which HBV DNA, antigens, and antibodies are measurable (and transaminases elevated) during acute HBV infection and resolution. Note that the timing can vary significantly between patients and that the pattern in chronic infection differs.

The window period is an interval in which HBsAg is no longer measurable, anti-HBs is not yet measurable, and only Anti-HBc and Anti-HBe can be detected.

HBV DNA: hepatitis B virus DNA; HBsAg: hepatitis B surface antigen; HBeAg: hepatitis B e antigen; Anti-HBc IgM: anti-hepatitis B core antigen IgM antibody; Anti-HBc total: anti-HBc IgM + anti-HBc IgG (conventionally measured together); Anti-HBs: anti-hepatitis B surface antigen antibody; Anti-HBe: anti-hepatitis Be antigen antibody

C) INCORRECT:

The hallmark of ongoing HBV infection is the persistence of surface antigen (HBsAg) and the absence of surface antibody (anti-HBs).

D) INCORRECT:

Prior hepatitis B immunization is typically associated with a negative surface antigen (HBsAg), a positive anti-surface antibody (anti-HBs), and a negative e antigen (HBeAg), as seen here, but a negative anti-core antibody (anti-HBc) on serology.

E) INCORRECT:

A positive immunoglobulin G-type anti-core antibody (anti-HBc) with negative e antigen (HBeAg) is consistent with an inactive carrier state, but the hallmark of ongoing HBV infection is the persistence of surface antigen (HBsAg) and the absence of surface antibody (anti-HBs).

B) CORRECT:

C) INCORRECT:

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic expressing concern about contracting hepatitis B after her partner was recently diagnosed with the infection. She is sexually active with him and has never received the hepatitis B vaccine. Physical examination is normal. Laboratory tests to determine her HBV status are pending.
Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate to reduce her likelihood of infection during intercourse?

choices.text: Delay sexual activity until serologic tests return
Rely on intravaginal spermicides for HBV prevention

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Delaying sexual activity does not actively reduce the risk of HBV transmission from an infected partner. Immediate protective measures, such as initiating the hepatitis B vaccine series and using barrier protection, are necessary. Pending serologic tests only provide retrospective information and do not protect against future exposures.

B) CORRECT:

Consistent condom use serves as a physical barrier, preventing the exchange of bodily fluids, which is the primary route of hepatitis B virus (HBV) transmission during sexual contact. This method is crucial for individuals with uncertain or incomplete vaccination status, as it reduces the likelihood of viral exposure. Barrier protection limits contact between the infected partner’s secretions and the mucosal surfaces of the uninfected partner, minimizing transmission risk.

Key learning point: For individuals with a partner diagnosed with hepatitis B, using condoms during intercourse is recommended to reduce the risk of transmission.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravaginal spermicides are designed to inhibit sperm motility and do not prevent blood-borne pathogen transmission, such as HBV. They lack antiviral properties and do not form a physical barrier to block infectious fluids. Evidence-based practices recommend immunization or barrier protection for HBV prevention.

D) INCORRECT:

Antiviral agents manage established hepatitis B infections by suppressing viral replication but do not provide immediate protection post-exposure. They are not effective in preventing infection establishment when administered immediately after exposure in unvaccinated individuals. Post-exposure management emphasizes interventions that neutralize the virus or stimulate a rapid immune response.

questions.text: An asymptomatic 28-year-old healthcare worker has a positive HBsAb, but negative HBcAb and HBeAb on routine labs. Which best explains these serologic results?

choices.text: Acute infection in the window period

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic active hepatitis B is associated with persistent hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and often hepatitis B core antibody (HBcAb) due to ongoing viral replication. The presence of HBsAb and absence of HBcAb and HBeAb in this serologic profile are inconsistent with chronic active hepatitis B.

B) INCORRECT:

In resolved hepatitis B infection, antibodies against the core antigen (HBcAb) are present, as natural infection involves exposure to the entire virus. The absence of HBcAb in this serologic profile, with only HBsAb being positive, indicates immunity from vaccination rather than resolved infection.

C) INCORRECT:

During the window period of acute hepatitis B infection, antibodies against the core antigen (anti-HBc), particularly IgM, are detectable. The absence of anti-HBc and the presence of anti-HBs in this serologic profile indicate immunity from vaccination, not acute infection.

D) CORRECT:

Hepatitis B vaccination uses the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) to stimulate an immune response, resulting in the production of hepatitis B surface antibodies (HBsAb). This vaccine-induced immunity does not involve exposure to the core antigen (HBcAg) or e antigen (HBeAg), so antibodies against these proteins (HBcAb and HBeAb) are absent. The serologic profile of positive HBsAb with negative HBcAb and HBeAb is indicative of immunity from vaccination, not natural infection.

Key learning point: In individuals vaccinated against hepatitis B, the presence of HBsAb indicates immunity, while HBcAb and HBeAb are not present as they are markers of past or current infection.

questions.text: A 32-year-old nurse undergoes hepatitis B serology after a needle stick. Her results: negative HBsAg, positive anti-HBc, and positive anti-HBs. What best describes her current status?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Susceptibility to hepatitis B is indicated by the absence of all markers, including anti-HBc and anti-HBs. The presence of anti-HBs indicates protective immunity, while anti-HBc confirms past exposure. The negative HBsAg rules out active infection, and the serologic profile is inconsistent with susceptibility.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic hepatitis B infection is defined by persistent HBsAg positivity. The absence of HBsAg excludes ongoing viral replication. The combination of positive anti-HBc and anti-HBs, with negative HBsAg, indicates resolved infection and protective immunity, not chronic infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Vaccination-induced immunity is characterized by isolated anti-HBs positivity without anti-HBc. The presence of anti-HBc indicates past natural infection, as the core antigen is not part of the vaccine. The serologic pattern of negative HBsAg, positive anti-HBc, and positive anti-HBs suggests resolved natural infection, not immunity from vaccination alone.

D) CORRECT:

The serologic profile of negative hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), positive hepatitis B core antibody (anti-HBc), and positive hepatitis B surface antibody (anti-HBs) indicates resolved hepatitis B infection. The absence of HBsAg excludes active infection. Anti-HBc positivity signifies past exposure to the virus, as it is not produced in response to vaccination. The presence of anti-HBs denotes protective immunity, indicating recovery and long-term immunity from prior natural infection.

Key learning point: A serological profile with negative HBsAg, positive anti-HBc, and positive anti-HBs indicates immunity due to past natural infection with hepatitis B.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic for a routine examination. He reports feeling well and has no significant past medical history. He emigrated from a region where hepatitis B is endemic several years ago. Physical examination is normal, and liver function tests are within normal limits. Serologic testing shows HBsAg positive, anti-HBc (IgG) positive, anti-HBe positive, HBeAg negative, and anti-HBs negative.
Which of the following best describes his current hepatitis B infection status?

choices.text: Inactive carrier state of hepatitis B infection

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The serologic profile shows HBsAg positivity and anti-HBc IgG positivity, indicating chronic hepatitis B infection. The absence of HBeAg and presence of anti-HBe suggest low viral replication and minimal infectivity. Normal liver function tests further support an inactive carrier state, characterized by chronic infection without active liver inflammation or significant hepatocyte injury. The lack of anti-HBs indicates the infection has not been cleared, aligning with an inactive carrier state rather than acute, active, or resolved hepatitis B infection.

Key learning point: A serological profile with positive HBsAg, anti-HBc (IgG), and anti-HBe, but negative anti-HBs and HBeAg, indicates chronic hepatitis B infection, often in the inactive carrier state.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic active hepatitis B infection involves ongoing viral replication and liver inflammation, usually with HBeAg positivity and elevated liver enzymes. This patient has HBeAg negativity, anti-HBe positivity, and normal liver function tests, indicating a low replicative state rather than active hepatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Resolved hepatitis B infection is characterized by clearance of HBsAg and development of anti-HBs. This patient has persistent HBsAg, indicating ongoing infection. The absence of anti-HBs and presence of anti-HBe suggest low viral replication, not resolution.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute hepatitis B infection typically presents with HBsAg positivity and IgM anti-HBc, indicating recent exposure and active viral replication. This patient has IgG anti-HBc, suggesting past exposure. The presence of anti-HBe and absence of HBeAg indicate a chronic state rather than acute infection. Normal liver function tests and asymptomatic presentation further argue against acute hepatitis B.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old nurse is evaluated in the clinic following a needlestick injury from a known hepatitis B-positive patient. She mentions receiving multiple vaccinations as a child but cannot recall completing the hepatitis B series. She has no history of jaundice, fatigue, or significant illness. Laboratory testing shows HBsAg negative, Anti-HBc IgG negative, and Anti-HBs positive. Complete blood count is normal. She has no previous antibody titers available. Her physician explains that interpretation of these findings is important for guiding prophylaxis measures.
Which of the following best explains her current hepatitis B serologic findings?

choices.text: Active chronic hepatitis B infection requiring treatment
Resolved infection after an acute hepatitis B episode
No protective immunity and high susceptibility to hepatitis B
Immunity conferred by prior vaccination against hepatitis B

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Active chronic hepatitis B infection is marked by positive HBsAg and usually positive Anti-HBc IgG, indicating ongoing viral replication. This patient's negative HBsAg and Anti-HBc IgG, with positive Anti-HBs, indicate immunity from vaccination, not active infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Resolved hepatitis B infection typically shows positive Anti-HBs and Anti-HBc IgG. This patient's serology, with positive Anti-HBs and negative Anti-HBc IgG, suggests vaccination-induced immunity, not resolved infection. Additionally, there is no clinical history of hepatitis B infection.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of Anti-HBs without HBsAg or Anti-HBc IgG indicates successful vaccination and protective immunity. Absence of Anti-HBs would suggest susceptibility, but this patient's positive Anti-HBs confirms immunity.

D) CORRECT:

The serologic pattern of negative hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), negative hepatitis B core antibody (Anti-HBc IgG), and positive hepatitis B surface antibody (Anti-HBs) indicates immunity from vaccination. Vaccination induces an immune response against HBsAg, leading to Anti-HBs production without Anti-HBc formation. In contrast, natural infection would result in antibodies to both core and surface antigens. The absence of HBsAg confirms no active viral replication, guiding prophylaxis decisions after exposure.

Key learning point: A positive Anti-HBsAg with a negative Anti-HBc IgG indicates immunity to hepatitis B due to vaccination, not past infection.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with hepatitis B surface antigen positivity delivers a female infant at 38 weeks’ gestation. She has been taking prenatal vitamins but did not receive antiviral therapy during pregnancy. Both mother and infant are stable postpartum.
Which of the following interventions is most appropriate to prevent vertical transmission of hepatitis B to the newborn?

choices.text: Hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B immunoglobulin
Maternal antiviral therapy now and defer newborn prophylaxis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) provides immediate but short-term protection against hepatitis B. It does not induce active immunity, which is necessary for long-term protection. Without the hepatitis B vaccine, the infant remains at risk for infection once the passive antibodies from HBIG wane. The vaccine is needed to stimulate the infant's immune system to produce its own antibodies for lasting immunity.

B) CORRECT:

Infants born to hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg)–positive mothers should receive both hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and the hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth. HBIG provides immediate passive immunity by neutralizing the virus, while the vaccine initiates active immunity for long-term protection. This dual approach significantly reduces the risk of vertical transmission. The timing is critical, as administering these interventions within the first 12 hours maximizes their effectiveness in preventing infection.

Key learning point: Newborns of hepatitis B surface antigen positive mothers should receive both hepatitis B vaccination and hepatitis B immunoglobulin within 12 hours of birth to prevent vertical transmission of the virus.

C) INCORRECT:

The hepatitis B vaccine induces long-term immunity but requires time to develop protective antibody levels. In the context of maternal hepatitis B surface antigen positivity, the risk of perinatal transmission is high, and the vaccine alone does not provide immediate protection. Hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) is needed to offer immediate passive immunity and neutralize the virus at the time of exposure.

D) INCORRECT:

Maternal antiviral therapy during pregnancy can reduce hepatitis B viral load, but immediate neonatal prophylaxis is essential to prevent vertical transmission. Administering hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and the hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth is crucial for neutralizing the virus the infant may have been exposed to during delivery. Postpartum maternal antiviral therapy alone does not provide the necessary immediate protection for the newborn.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old G2P1 woman with chronic hepatitis B infection has just delivered a male infant at 39 weeks. Prenatal records confirm persistent HBsAg positivity. The infant is 1 hour old, weighs 3.2 kg, and has Apgar scores of 8 and 9 at one and five minutes, respectively. Physical examination is normal.
Which of the following prophylactic measures is most appropriate to prevent vertical transmission of hepatitis B in this newborn?

choices.text: Hepatitis B immunoglobulin alone within 12 hours of birth
Concomitant administration of hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B immunoglobulin within 12 hours of birth
Oral antiviral prophylaxis for the infant
Hepatitis B vaccine alone prior to hospital discharge

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) provides short-term passive immunity by neutralizing the virus but does not induce long-term immunologic memory. In newborns of HBsAg-positive mothers, combining HBIG with the hepatitis B vaccine is necessary to initiate an active immune response, ensuring sustained protection against the virus.

B) CORRECT:

For newborns of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) positive mothers, early immunoprophylaxis is crucial to prevent vertical transmission. Administering hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) provides immediate passive immunity by neutralizing circulating virus particles. Concurrently, the hepatitis B vaccine initiates active immunity, promoting a sustained antibody response. This dual approach combines immediate and long-term protection, minimizing the risk of chronic hepatitis B infection. Both interventions should be administered within 12 hours of birth to maximize efficacy.

Key learning point: Newborns of hepatitis B surface antigen positive mothers should receive both hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B immunoglobulin within 12 hours of birth to prevent vertical transmission of hepatitis B.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral antiviral prophylaxis is not recommended for preventing hepatitis B transmission in newborns. The effective approach is passive-active immunoprophylaxis with hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and the hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth. No oral antiviral has been validated for safety or efficacy in neonates for this purpose.

D) INCORRECT:

While the hepatitis B vaccine is essential for developing long-term immunity, it does not provide immediate protection. In neonates born to HBsAg-positive mothers, immediate passive immunization with hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) is also necessary to prevent early vertical transmission. The vaccine alone leaves a vulnerable period immediately after birth, during which the infant is at risk of infection.

questions.text:
A newborn infant is delivered to a 29-year-old mother in the Maternity Ward. The mother tested positive for hepatitis B surface antigen during her third trimester and completed the recommended prenatal care. The infant received hepatitis B vaccine and HBIG within 12 hours of birth. The infant is healthy with normal vital signs.
What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding breastfeeding?

choices.text: Delay breastfeeding for at least 2 weeks to reduce risk of transmission
Formula feeding until the infant completes the vaccine series
Exclusive breastfeeding, as the newborn is protected by immunoprophylaxis
Limit breastfeeding until maternal viral load is confirmed to be undetectable

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Delaying breastfeeding is unnecessary because the infant received HBIG and the hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth, effectively preventing perinatal transmission. Breast milk does not significantly transmit hepatitis B, and immediate breastfeeding is supported by evidence-based guidelines, promoting early bonding and nutritional benefits.

B) INCORRECT:

Formula feeding is unnecessary because the infant received effective prophylaxis with HBIG and the hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth. Breast milk does not contain sufficient quantities of the hepatitis B virus to cause infection in immunized infants. Breastfeeding provides significant nutritional and immunologic benefits and is safe for infants born to hepatitis B–positive mothers with proper immunoprophylaxis.

C) CORRECT:

Breastfeeding is safe for infants born to hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg)-positive mothers when the infant receives hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG) and the hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth. This immunoprophylaxis provides immediate passive immunity and stimulates active immune protection, reducing the risk of vertical transmission to less than 10%. Organizations such as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) endorse breastfeeding in this context, as the benefits of breastfeeding outweigh the negligible risk of hepatitis B transmission.

Key learning point: Breastfeeding is safe and encouraged in infants born to HBsAg positive mothers if the infant receives hepatitis B vaccine and HBIG shortly after birth.

D) INCORRECT:

Limiting breastfeeding based on maternal viral load is unnecessary. Hepatitis B is not transmitted through breast milk, especially when the infant receives appropriate prophylaxis. The infant's receipt of HBIG and the hepatitis B vaccine effectively prevents transmission, regardless of the mother's viral load.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old East Asian man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of fatigue and malaise. He reports tiring quickly with physical activity and has mild abdominal discomfort. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. He drinks alcohol on weekends and holidays, does not smoke, and does not use other substances. He works as a tattoo artist. His vitals are normal; BMI is 19. On examination, he appears fatigued. Pulmonary and cardiac examinations are normal. His abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation, and there is mild hepatomegaly.


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
152 g/L (125–170)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
10.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Platelet count, blood
270 × 109/L (130–380)


Alanine aminotransferase (ALT), blood
75 IU/L (17–63)


Aspartate aminotransferase (AST), blood
80 IU/L (15–37)


Bilirubin, total, blood
14 μmol/L (3–17)


Albumin, blood
40 g/L (34–50)


HBsAg
Positive


Anti-HBc IgG
Positive


Anti-HBs
Negative


Anti-HBc IgM
Negative


Anti-HCV
Negative


Without treatment of his current condition, which one of the following is he at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lichen planus is more strongly associated with hepatitis C than hepatitis B.

B) INCORRECT:

Essential mixed cryoglobulinemia is more strongly associated with hepatitis C than hepatitis B.

C) INCORRECT:

AA amyloidosis is a potential complication of CHB, but this patient has an even greater risk for a different complication.

D) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is more commonly associated with chronic hepatitis C than with hepatitis B. Membranous glomerulonephritis is a common renal complication of chronic hepatitis B, but this patient has an even greater risk for a complication that affects a different organ system.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with CHB can be asymptomatic or present with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, malaise, decreased appetite, and abdominal pain. Ongoing hepatic inflammation due to CHB increases the risk of cirrhosis, which can cause hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and both CHB and chronic hepatitis C are also independent risk factors for HCC.

Key learning point: Chronic hepatitis B infection significantly increases the risk of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma due to ongoing hepatic inflammation.
questions.hint: Positive HBsAg and anti-HBc IgG indicate chronic hepatitis B.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-week history of generalized fatigue, mild fever, abdominal pain, and nausea. On examination, she has mild scleral icterus. The liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin and is tender. Laboratory studies show:


Bilirubin, total, blood
62 μmol/L (3–17)


Bilirubin, direct (conjugated), blood
41 μmol/L (2–9)


Alkaline phosphatase, blood
102 IU/L (50–136)


Aspartate aminotransferase (AST), blood
488 IU/L (15–37)


Alanine aminotransferase (ALT), blood

798 IU/L (17–63)


Hepatitis A IgG antibody, blood
Positive


Hepatitis B surface antigen, blood
Positive


Hepatitis B core IgG antibody, blood
Positive


Hepatitis B e antigen, blood
Positive


Hepatitis C antibody, blood
Negative


Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The positive anti-HAV IgG titers in this patient indicate either vaccination or an old infection with hepatitis A virus (HAV). As both result in lifelong immunity, this laboratory constellation rules out acute infection. Additionally, if the patient had an acute HAV infection, the serology would be positive for HAV-IgM antibodies.

B) INCORRECT:

The largest group of patients with chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infections are inactive carriers. In these patients, the immune system's response slows viral replication, which is why HBeAg (an indicator of viral replication) would be undetectable, whereas it is positive in this patient. Additionally, due to the low number of viral particles in inactive HBV infection, the disease burden would be very low and this patient's findings (e.g., elevated transaminases, icterus) would be unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Because the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is positive, the possible differentials are limited to acute, active chronic, and inactive chronic hepatitis B. HBsAg is only negative in an infected patient during the window period or if the virus is successfully cleared from circulation. In acute infection, IgM antibodies against the core antigen would be expected, however, as opposed to IgG antibodies.

D) INCORRECT:

For hepatitis B virus (HBV) to be considered resolved, all viral particles must be cleared from the host. In contrast to this patient, in a patient with a resolved HBV infection, viral antigens (HBsAg, HBeAg) would be undetectable, but antibodies against the viral antigens would remain detectable (anti-HBs, anti-HBc).

E) CORRECT:

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is positive in patients with either an acute, active chronic, or an inactive chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. HBsAg is only negative in infected patients during the window period of HBV or if the infection was successfully cleared. IgG antibodies against the hepatitis B core antigen (Anti-HBc IgG) indicate either active or inactive chronic infection. The e antigen is only present during phases of viremia, which occur in acute or active chronic infections. A positive IgG antibody test rules out an acute infection, which would instead show IgM antibodies. This patient therefore most likely has an active chronic HBV infection.

Key learning point: Active chronic hepatitis B infection is indicated by positive HBsAg, anti-HBc IgG, and HBeAg, reflecting ongoing viral replication and chronicity.
Image Description:

The hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is found on the outer wall of the virions lipid bilayer and confirms the presence of the virus in the blood. HBsAg is the first indicator of infection and can be detected as early as 1 week after infection. An infected hepatocyte may also release the hepatitis B envelope antigen (HBeAg), a protein produced by the virus that serves as an indicator of active viral replication.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of increasing generalized fatigue. He reports a 5.4 kg weight loss over the past 6 months. He has numerous tattoos, several of which were acquired while backpacking through Southeast Asia as a young man. On examination, the liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show a serum α-fetoprotein of 410 μg/L (≤ 9.0). CT scan of the abdomen reveals a 3.5 x 2 x 1.5 cm mass in segment 6 of the liver. Which one of the following interventions most likely would have prevented this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CA 19–9 is a tumor marker that is produced by numerous forms of cancer and is primarily used for monitoring treatment response and detecting cancer recurrence. However, it is not a reliable screening or diagnostic marker because of its low sensitivity and low specificity.

B) CORRECT:

Up to 50% of cases of HCC occur secondary to chronic hepatitis B (HBV) infection. Although the majority of such cases (approx. 80%) are preceded by liver cirrhosis, HCC can also arise directly from chronic HBV infection. A history of multiple tattoos that were obtained in countries with a higher prevalence of HBV and hepatitis C virus, as in this patient, should raise the suspicion of HBV infection. HBV vaccination is recommended for all unvaccinated individuals.

Key learning point: Hepatitis B vaccination is the most effective intervention to prevent hepatocellular carcinoma, especially in individuals at risk for chronic hepatitis B infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Penicillamine is a chelating agent that is used to reduce extremely high levels of copper in patients with Wilson disease, which typically manifests at a young age (< 35 years) with progressive hepatitis (or even cirrhosis) and neurological disorders (extrapyramidal motor symptoms and/or cognitive impairment). These features are not consistent with this patient's presentation. Also, the absence of Kayser-Fleischer rings makes this diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Regular phlebotomies are performed to manage patients with hemochromatosis. Although this condition can lead to hepatocellular carcinoma, it is usually preceded by progressive liver cirrhosis, and other findings, including fatigue, hyperpigmentation, type 2 diabetes mellitus ("bronze diabetes"), hepatomegaly, and symmetrical arthralgia. This patient's symptoms are not consistent with hemochromatosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Obesity and diabetes mellitus are risk factors for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Excess supply of nutrients in the liver and increased insulin resistance result in accumulation of fat in liver cells. Patients generally do not exhibit signs of hepatic disease in the early stages of NAFLD, but progression to cirrhosis with an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) can occur. This patient does not have a history of obesity, diabetes, hepatitis, or cirrhosis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with weight loss, fatigue, and an enlarged liver. A mass on an abdominal CT scan in the context of massively increased α-fetoprotein is highly suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

questions.text: You are seeing a 67-year-old woman from Southeast Asia who presents to your clinic to establish care. She reports no concerns. Her medical history includes hypertension, prior hysterectomy, and previous treatment for latent tuberculosis. Physical examination is unremarkable. Hepatitis B serology shows negative surface antigen, positive anti-surface antibody, positive IgG-type anti-core antibody, and negative e antigen. Which one of the following clinical states is indicated by her hepatitis B serology findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend onetime screening for hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection in all individuals ≥ 18 years old. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends HBV screening in a narrower group of people, namely those who are pregnant and those with risk factors; this latter group includes patients from areas where HBV infection is endemic, such as parts of Southeast Asia.

Most adults who are exposed to HBV clear the infection spontaneously, but a small percentage (≤ 5%) develop persistent viremia and chronic infection. HBV surface antigen becomes detectable in the blood 4 to 10 weeks after exposure, followed by anti-core antibodies (initially, immunoglobulin M-type). In most cases, the HBV e antigen also becomes detectable around this time.

In patients who experience a self-limited course, HBV anti-surface antibody levels then rise and are accompanied by clearance of the antigens and viremia. Anti-surface antibody and immunoglobulin G-type anti-core antibodies indicate cleared HBV infection, whereas anti-surface antibody alone indicates prior HBV vaccination.

The hallmark of ongoing HBV infection is persistence of surface antigen and absence of surface antibody. A positive HBV e antigen, a marker of replication and infectivity in persistent infection, also indicates an elevated risk for hepatocellular carcinoma.

Key learning point: A hepatitis B serology panel that is positive for both anti-surface antibody and immunoglobulin G-type anti-core antibody indicates prior hepatitis B virus infection.
Image Description:

Schematic depiction of the time frames in which HBV DNA, antigens, and antibodies are measurable (and transaminases elevated) during acute HBV infection and resolution. Note that the timing can vary significantly between patients and that the pattern in chronic infection differs.

The window period is an interval in which HBsAg is no longer measurable, anti-HBs is not yet measurable, and only Anti-HBc and Anti-HBe can be detected.

HBV DNA: hepatitis B virus DNA; HBsAg: hepatitis B surface antigen; HBeAg: hepatitis B e antigen; Anti-HBc IgM: anti-hepatitis B core antigen IgM antibody; Anti-HBc total: anti-HBc IgM + anti-HBc IgG (conventionally measured together); Anti-HBs: anti-hepatitis B surface antigen antibody; Anti-HBe: anti-hepatitis Be antigen antibody

B) INCORRECT:

Prior hepatitis B immunization is typically associated with a negative surface antigen (HBsAg), a positive anti-surface antibody (anti-HBs), and a negative e antigen (HBeAg), as seen here, but a negative anti-core antibody (anti-HBc) on serology.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute hepatitis B infection is typically associated with a positive surface antigen (HBsAg), negative anti-surface antibody (anti-HBs), positive immunoglobulin M-type anti-core antibody (anti-HBc), and a positive e antigen (HBeAg) on serology.

D) INCORRECT:

The hallmark of ongoing HBV infection is the persistence of surface antigen (HBsAg) and the absence of surface antibody (anti-HBs).

E) INCORRECT:

A positive immunoglobulin G-type anti-core antibody (anti-HBc) with negative e antigen (HBeAg) is consistent with an inactive carrier state, but the hallmark of ongoing HBV infection is the persistence of surface antigen (HBsAg) and the absence of surface antibody (anti-HBs).

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of nausea, vomiting, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain. She immigrated from India 6 weeks ago. Vital signs: T 37.8°C (100.0°F); BP 110/70 mmHg; HR 105/min; R 18/min; oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Physical examination shows scleral icterus, mild confusion, asterixis, mild right upper quadrant tenderness, and no peripheral edema. Laboratory studies reveal ALT 1,425 U/L, AST 1,113 U/L, alkaline phosphatase 180 U/L, total bilirubin 13.5 mg/dL, INR 3.2, platelet count 125,000/μL, haptoglobin 150 mg/dL (normal 45-200 mg/dL), and glucose 65 mg/dL. Viral hepatitis serologies are HAV IgM negative, HBsAg negative, HBsAb positive, HBcAb negative, anti-HCV negative. Urinalysis shows trace protein and no glucose. Abdominal ultrasound demonstrates normal liver echogenicity and no signs of biliary obstruction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patient's hepatitis B serology shows HBsAb positive and HBcAb negative, which indicates immunity from HBV vaccination rather than active infection. HBsAg negative further rules out active hepatitis B infection.

B) INCORRECT:

HELLP syndrome is characterized by hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets. While this patient has borderline low platelets (125,000/μL), the normal haptoglobin level indicates no hemolysis, making HELLP syndrome unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

The hallmarks of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy are pruritus and elevated total serum bile acid levels. While transaminases may be grossly elevated, bilirubin levels are usually normal or only mildly elevated. Acute liver failure with coagulopathy and encephalopathy, as seen in this patient, is uncommon in intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

While preeclampsia with severe features can present with impaired liver function, preeclampsia requires hypertension (≥140/90 mmHg) and significant proteinuria (e.g., urine dipstick >2+ protein) as diagnostic criteria. This patient has normal blood pressure (110/70 mmHg) and only trace proteinuria, ruling out preeclampsia.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Hepatitis E infection is endemic in developing countries including India and commonly causes fulminant hepatic failure in pregnant women. Up to 20% of pregnant individuals with HEV infection develop a fulminant course that is life-threatening for both mother and fetus. The timing is consistent with HEV's incubation period of 2-8 weeks, as the patient immigrated 6 weeks ago. The patient's recent immigration from an endemic region, negative hepatitis A/B/C serologies, and presentation with fulminant hepatic failure, as evidence by rapidly progressive severe acute liver injury with encephalopathy and coagulopathy, make HEV infection the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old nurse presents to the emergency department two months after a needlestick injury in the operating room. Hepatitis serology studies are negative for hepatitis B surface antigen, hepatitis B e antigen, and hepatitis B core antibody and positive for hepatitis B surface antibody.  What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: No prior hepatitis B vaccination or exposure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Individuals with acute hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection test positive for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and hepatitis B core antibody (anti-HBc) as these are the earliest serological markers of recent HBV exposure. The absence of both HBsAg and anti-HBc excludes acute infection.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient tested positive for hepatitis B surface antibody (anti-HBs) and negative for hepatitis B core antibody (anti-HBc), which indicates prior hepatitis B vaccination. Anti-HBs typically appears within 3 months of vaccination and provides protective immunity against hepatitis B virus. The absence of anti-HBc distinguishes vaccination-induced immunity from immunity due to resolved natural infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic hepatitis B virus infection is characterized by persistent hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) positivity for more than 6 months along with a positive hepatitis B core antibody (anti-HBc) test. The absence of both HBsAg and anti-HBc excludes chronic infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with resolved hepatitis B virus infection test positive for hepatitis B core antibody (anti-HBc) and hepatitis B surface antibodies as anti-HBc indicates prior exposure to hepatitis B core antigen during natural infection. The absence of anti-HBc excludes resolved infection.

E) INCORRECT:

The positive hepatitis B surface antibody (anti-HBs) test indicates immunity to hepatitis B virus. Individuals with no hepatitis B vaccination or exposure test negative for all serological markers, including anti-HBs.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of progressive fatigue, nausea, and right upper quadrant abdominal pain. Over the past few days, he has noticed his skin and eyes turning yellow and his urine becoming dark. He reports having a new sexual partner 3 months ago and has been inconsistent with condom use. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). He has scleral icterus. Physical examination shows tender hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies show an ALT of 1500 U/L and a total bilirubin of 6.5 mg/dL. Hepatitis serologies are positive for HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Arrange for close follow-up and supportive care

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B immune globulin provides passive immunity and is used for postexposure prophylaxis in unvaccinated individuals exposed to the virus, such as through a needlestick injury or sexual contact, or for newborns of HBsAg-positive mothers. It is not effective as a treatment for an established, active infection such as this patient's.

B) INCORRECT:

Liver transplantation is a life-saving intervention for patients with fulminant hepatic failure or end-stage liver disease from chronic infection. This patient has acute hepatitis without signs of fulminant failure, such as altered mental status or severe coagulopathy, so referral for transplantation is not indicated at this time.

C) CORRECT:

In over 95% of immunocompetent adults, acute hepatitis B infection is a self-limited illness that resolves spontaneously without specific therapy. Therefore, the mainstay of management is supportive care, including rest, hydration, nutrition, and avoidance of hepatotoxic substances such as alcohol and acetaminophen. Close outpatient follow-up is essential to monitor for the rare development of fulminant hepatic failure and to ensure eventual viral clearance (loss of HBsAg) and seroconversion (development of anti-HBs).

D) INCORRECT:

A liver biopsy is an invasive procedure used to assess the grade and stage of chronic liver disease or to establish a diagnosis when it is uncertain. In this case, the diagnosis of acute viral hepatitis is clearly established by the classic clinical presentation and definitive serologic markers. A biopsy would not add useful information for initial management and would expose the patient to unnecessary risks, such as bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Antiviral therapy with agents such as tenofovir is a cornerstone of treatment for chronic hepatitis B infection. However, it is not indicated for uncomplicated acute hepatitis B. It is reserved for severe or fulminant acute cases, characterized by signs such as hepatic encephalopathy, an INR > 1.5, or persistent, severe jaundice, none of which this patient has.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation, including right upper quadrant pain and scleral icterus, as well as serologies (positive HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM), is consistent with acute hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nurse receives a needlestick from a hepatitis B–positive patient. Which blood test typically becomes positive first in acute HBV infection?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is the earliest serologic marker detectable after exposure to the hepatitis B virus. It appears during the incubation period, before clinical symptoms manifest, indicating active infection. The presence of HBsAg is crucial for early diagnosis, especially in healthcare settings where prompt intervention is necessary. Following HBsAg, other markers such as immunoglobulin M anti-hepatitis B core (IgM anti-HBc) appear, confirming the acute nature of the infection.

Key learning point: The first serological marker to appear in the blood after exposure to hepatitis B virus is HBsAg, indicating an active infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) indicates active viral replication and high infectivity but appears later than hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) in the course of infection. HBeAg provides information on disease activity but is not the earliest marker.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-hepatitis B surface (anti-HBs) appears after the clearance of the virus, indicating recovery and immunity. It is not an early marker of acute infection, as it follows the presence of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and other early markers.

D) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin M anti-hepatitis B core (IgM anti-HBc) is a marker for acute hepatitis B infection but appears after hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg). IgM anti-HBc confirms acute infection once HBsAg is present, typically emerging around the onset of symptoms.

Positive anti-HBs and IgG anti-HBc with negative HBeAg is characteristic of complete recovery from acute hepatitis B infection (immunity due to natural infection). Most adults who develop acute hepatitis B infection would recover completely and be asymptomatic, as seen here. However, hepatic transaminase activity would be normal and HBV DNA would be undetectable in patients who recover completely.
Image Description:

Schematic depiction of the time frames in which HBV DNA, antigens, and antibodies are measurable (and transaminases elevated) during acute HBV infection and resolution. Note that the timing can vary significantly between patients and that the pattern in chronic infection differs.

The window period is an interval in which HBsAg is no longer measurable, anti-HBs is not yet measurable, and only Anti-HBc and Anti-HBe can be detected.

HBV DNA: hepatitis B virus DNA; HBsAg: hepatitis B surface antigen; HBeAg: hepatitis B e antigen; Anti-HBc IgM: anti-hepatitis B core antigen IgM antibody; Anti-HBc total: anti-HBc IgM + anti-HBc IgG (conventionally measured together); Anti-HBs: anti-hepatitis B surface antigen antibody; Anti-HBe: anti-hepatitis Be antigen antibody

B) INCORRECT:

Positive IgG anti-HBc with negative HBeAg and anti-HBs is characteristic of inactive chronic hepatitis B infection. 5–10% of adults who develop acute hepatitis B infection will develop chronic hepatitis B infection. However, patients with inactive chronic hepatitis B infection would typically have normal hepatic transaminase activity and an HBV DNA load < 2000 IU/L.

C) INCORRECT:

Positive anti-HBs with negative HBeAg and anti-HBc is characteristic of immunity against hepatitis B as a result of vaccination. A different set of findings would be expected in this patient who developed acute viral hepatitis B infection in the past.

D) INCORRECT:

Positive IgM anti-HBc with negative HBeAg, anti-HBs, and IgG anti-HBc is characteristic of the window period of acute hepatitis B infection. A different set of findings would be expected in an asymptomatic patient who already had acute viral hepatitis B infection.

E) CORRECT:

Up to 10% of patients who develop acute hepatitis B infection will develop chronic hepatitis B infection, which is characterized by the persistence of HBsAg and HBV DNA for more than 6 months after the initial infection, and the absence of anti-HBs. IgG anti-HBc may be present or absent with chronic hepatitis B infection. Chronic hepatitis B infection can be classified as “active” (marked viral replication characterized by increased HBeAg) or “inactive” (low or no viral replication characterized by an absence of serum HBeAg). Patients with active chronic hepatitis B would have an HBV DNA load > 2000 IU/L and/or increased hepatic transaminase levels.
Image Description:

The main serological feature of active chronic HBV infection is the persistence of HBV DNA and the antigens HBsAg and HBeAg despite resolution of acute infection. Transaminase levels may be normal or increased and fluctuate between periods of active and inactive chronic infection. For inactive chronic HBV infection, Anti-HBe develops and HBeAg is no longer detectable.

F) INCORRECT:

Positive HBeAg and IgM anti-HBc with negative anti-HBs is characteristic of acute viral hepatitis B infection, which would cause increased hepatic transaminase activity and increased HBV DNA load. A different set of findings would be expected in this asymptomatic patient who presents nine months after the initial episode of acute viral hepatitis B infection.
questions.hint: This patient who previously had acute hepatitis B infection and currently presents with increased hepatic transaminase activity and an HBV DNA load of 4286 U/L most likely has active chronic hepatitis B infection.
